Comment: In this light game both me and my opponent blundered, but the win was mine because of a psychological effect: I went on playing trying to create as many difficulties as I could for my opponent, and he wasn't accurate enough to properly defend / counterattack. So it went:
? White gives me a free tempo. If he wanted to unbalance me, he's wrong, since I will go on just like planned, but with an extra tempo.
? White gives me a free tempo. If he wanted to unbalance me, he's wrong, since I will go on just like planned, but with an extra tempo.

I "lose" it preventing Bb4+. Not dangerous, but the idea is to restrict white.
A strong pawn chain I think I can attack. All this is calculated by experience through a number of games.

The best.

Now the game is all of it owns. A new situation for me. I am undeveloped, but I have to find the way to get meaningful developement. Be7 won't do. I have to be very aware of b5, since the a6's weakness will hurt me in the endgame.

? Self-blocking himself, and isolating the doubled pawns (true they are safe, for now).
? Self-blocking himself, and isolating the doubled pawns (true they are safe, for now).

Not the Bishop. Because this move is much more threatening for white. I can't allow him to play his way. Bg4+ was just covered and my B would have been doing almost nothing, in this situation. I have other tricks in my sleeve.
! Sensible. No good way to defend. Ra5 loses it, sooner or later.
This is "meaningful developement" :-)
!? I expected Ra3.
!? I expected Ra3.
If Ra3, Bc4 and the exchange is ok to me.
If Ra3, Bc4 and the exchange is ok to me.
A good idea is force white to exchange, but I didn't get my developement target, so I have to play aggressively and hope for the right moment to develop.
NxBe6 could be a good idea, intending to use h6 as a dev square for my minors.
?? I was so sure he would have defended the R that I didn't consider he actually did not!
Now the N is safely developed here, with a good position (Nf5...) and my B is safe on b3. I was now so glad I didn't play b5!

Fantastic. If g5, Nf5 threats Ng3 (if the h pawn is moved).
Now this move is sensible. I have to remember, though, that this bishop is condemned to take the WN should it jump to c5.
